Articles.Content: hello, is there a saturn v analougue out there with payload of 120 to low kerbin orbit and 40 to trans-mun injection? also requires good twr (1.7-2.2)
There is a tutorial on the wiki, found at this link, that contains detailed instructions on creating a stock Saturn V and running it through an Apollo style CSM-based landing mission.

Mulbin's munbug series and my own saturn V should lift a bit less than 20 tons to a trans mÃƒÂ¼nar injection - and from the construction technique we used to make those would not be able to lift much more without adding several mainsails and jumbo tanks

A 40 tons to TMI 3 stage rocket like saturn V with stock parts would be quite a challenge. (severe risks of crushing the first stage with the rocket's weight in a 3 stage configuration)

Asparagus / booster assisted staging would be a much more likely candidate for this kind of weight

Edited October 17, 2013 by sgt_flyer

There is a tutorial on the wiki, found at this link, that contains detailed instructions on creating a stock Saturn V and running it through an Apollo style CSM-based landing mission.

i've done some calc. with that rocket and it gives 1.2 twr at launch. a payload of 120 tons will overload that rocket and the engines will not give enough thrust.

Edited October 17, 2013 by deepspacecreeper

hello, is there a saturn v analougue out there with payload of 120 to low kerbin orbit and 40 to trans-mun injection? also requires good twr (1.7-2.2)

These are contradictory requirements: 40t to the Mun doesn't need 120t to LKO, 13t of fuel will get 40t to a Mun intercept using a poodle.

Kerbin is not Earth!

Edit: FWIW I have made a 200t to LKO "classic" staged rocket, bracing it so that the stages don't collapse on the launchpad was painful.
I think you should use Mulbin's Munbug. It's the best stock Saturn V

I think you should use Mulbin's Munbug. It's the best stock Saturn V

I like sgt_flyer's: http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/35416-Saturn-V%28rev-2%29-Saturn-IB-and-Skylab

i meant at least
I used KWRocketry for my Saturn V.I actually got it to the Mun with fuel to spare.

My N-5 Moon rocket isnt a Saturn V, more of an N-1 but it's more then powerful enough to do all of what you are asking.

http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/56490-N-5-Moon-Rocket

Sorry to drege up an old thread, but here is a working fully stock saturn v (as of 25/05/17).  Happy to answer any related flight questions.

https://www.dropbox.com/s/2e15kcg7rqtmzho/Saturn V Stock.craft?dl=0

Stats: launch 696.408t

          orbit ~80t

          parts 305
